Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260, \u00a7 2A (desc.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, the statute of limitations for personal injury actions is set by Massachusetts General Laws. See Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 260, § 2A (describing limitation period for certain tort actions).

Mass. R. Civ. P. 26, 34 (discovery rules.raw_text: Mass. R. Civ. P. 26, 34 (discovery rules permitting disclosure of policies, staffing records, and safety rules)
Mass. R. Civ. P. 26, 34 (discovery rules.proposition: The following authorities reflect the governing negligence standards and related law applicable to the claims asserted in this Complaint. Plaintiff relies on these authorities and any other controlling statutes, rules, or caselaw cited at or before trial:

Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (foreseeability principle applied in duty analysis)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: The above statutes, Restatement sections, and cases are cited to reflect and support the well-established Massachusetts law principles that: a defendant who undertakes custodial or supervisory control over children owes a duty of reasonable care; that duty includes adequate staffing, active supervision, enforcement of safety rules, and reasonable measures to prevent foreseeable harm; and that a breach that is a proximate cause of harm gives rise to civil liability for resulting damages.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: Palsgraf is a New York Court of Appeals decision about the scope of duty and foreseeability in negligence generally, not about custodial or supervisory duties toward children, staffing, or enforcement of safety rules. Cardozo’s opinion concerns whether the railroad owed any duty to Mrs. Palsgraf based on foreseeability, and it ultimately finds no duty to her; it does not establish that an entity undertaking custodial control over children owes the specific supervisory obligations described or that breach of such duties gives rise to liability. Thus, it does not support the detailed Massachusetts custodial-duty proposition for which it is cited.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The risk reasonably to be perceived defines the duty to be obeyed, and risk imports relation; it is risk to another or to others within the range of apprehension… These cases aside, wrong is defined in terms of the natural or probable, at least when unintentional. … If the harm was not willful, he must show that the act as to him had possibilities of danger so many and apparent as to entitle him to be protected against the doing of it though the harm was unintended.”

McEvoy v. City of Boston, 416 Mass. 402.raw_text: McEvoy v. City of Boston, 416 Mass. 402 (1993) (duty and municipal obligations to maintain safe premises and supervise activities)
McEvoy v. City of Boston, 416 Mass. 402.proposition: The above statutes, Restatement sections, and cases are cited to reflect and support the well-established Massachusetts law principles that: a defendant who undertakes custodial or supervisory control over children owes a duty of reasonable care; that duty includes adequate staffing, active supervision, enforcement of safety rules, and reasonable measures to prevent foreseeable harm; and that a breach that is a proximate cause of harm gives rise to civil liability for resulting damages.
McEvoy v. City of Boston, 416 Mass. 402.support_reasoning: This case concerns employer liability for an intoxicated employee’s off-premises driving after an employer-sponsored party. It analyzes respondeat superior, social host liability, and special-relationship duties, and ultimately declines to impose a duty on the employer under the Restatement §§ 315 and 317 in these circumstances. It does not involve children, custodial or supervisory control over minors, staffing, active supervision, or enforcement of safety rules; if anything, it limits expansion of special-relationship duties rather than supporting the broad supervisory-duty proposition claimed.
McEvoy v. City of Boston, 416 Mass. 402.relevant_excerpt: “Although, as a general rule, there is no duty to protect others from the negligent or wrongful acts of third parties, based on social values and customs, such a duty may be premised on the existence of a special relationship between the negligent person and the person or entity on whom it is sought to impose liability. See Irwin v. Ware… Mullins v. Pine Manor College… Pucci v. Amherst Restaurant Enters…. In limited circumstances, ‘[w]e have discerned such a special relationship in cases addressing the liability of private parties to members of the general public where alcohol and driving were involved.’”

Lightfoot v. Gordon, 437 Mass. 543 (2002.raw_text: Lightfoot v. Gordon, 437 Mass. 543 (2002) (proximate cause and foreseeability in negligence)
Lightfoot v. Gordon, 437 Mass. 543 (2002.proposition: The above statutes, Restatement sections, and cases are cited to reflect and support the well-established Massachusetts law principles that: a defendant who undertakes custodial or supervisory control over children owes a duty of reasonable care; that duty includes adequate staffing, active supervision, enforcement of safety rules, and reasonable measures to prevent foreseeable harm; and that a breach that is a proximate cause of harm gives rise to civil liability for resulting damages.
Lightfoot v. Gordon, 437 Mass. 543 (2002.support_reasoning: The opinion deals exclusively with whether an employer has a right of contribution or indemnification against an offending employee under G.L. c. 151B and G.L. c. 231B. It does not involve negligence, proximate cause, foreseeability, or duties arising from custodial or supervisory control over children, nor does it address staffing, supervision, or safety rules. Thus it does not provide authority for the negligence-based duty and proximate cause principles described in the proposition.
Lightfoot v. Gordon, 437 Mass. 543 (2002.relevant_excerpt: "We decide today whether an employer has a right of contribution or indemnification against an offending employee for alleged violations of G. L. c. 151B... On appeal, EDI argues that an employer sued under G. L. c. 151B may seek contribution and indemnification from an offending employee pursuant to G. L. c. 231B, § 1 (a)."

Patterson v. City of Springfield, 410 Ma.raw_text: Patterson v. City of Springfield, 410 Mass. 403 (1991) (duty to supervise in municipal programs)
Patterson v. City of Springfield, 410 Ma.proposition: The above statutes, Restatement sections, and cases are cited to reflect and support the well-established Massachusetts law principles that: a defendant who undertakes custodial or supervisory control over children owes a duty of reasonable care; that duty includes adequate staffing, active supervision, enforcement of safety rules, and reasonable measures to prevent foreseeable harm; and that a breach that is a proximate cause of harm gives rise to civil liability for resulting damages.
Patterson v. City of Springfield, 410 Ma.case_name: Heller Financial v. Insurance Co. of North America
Patterson v. City of Springfield, 410 Ma.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns priority, assignment, and extinguishment of mortgages, contract formation regarding an estoppel letter, and Chapter 93A unfair practices in a commercial lending context. It does not involve custodial or supervisory control over children, duties of supervision, staffing, safety rules, or proximate cause of physical harm. Therefore it does not provide authority for the stated Massachusetts tort principle about supervisory duties toward children in municipal programs.
Patterson v. City of Springfield, 410 Ma.relevant_excerpt: The dispute between INA and Heller centers around whether the assignment of the 1981 mortgage from GBT to INA was valid and, if so, whether it should receive priority over the mortgage held by Heller. Heller argues that the 1981 mortgage was extinguished when GBT was paid $1,700,000 in full satisfaction of NERCO’s obligations to GBT… [discussion of mortgage law and equity].

Kennedy v. Town of Braintree, 60 Mass. A.raw_text: Kennedy v. Town of Braintree, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 200 (2004) (liability for negligent supervision)
Kennedy v. Town of Braintree, 60 Mass. A.proposition: The above statutes, Restatement sections, and cases are cited to reflect and support the well-established Massachusetts law principles that: a defendant who undertakes custodial or supervisory control over children owes a duty of reasonable care; that duty includes adequate staffing, active supervision, enforcement of safety rules, and reasonable measures to prevent foreseeable harm; and that a breach that is a proximate cause of harm gives rise to civil liability for resulting damages.
Kennedy v. Town of Braintree, 60 Mass. A.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal appeal about joinder of indictments, admission of prior bad acts evidence, sufficiency of the evidence for assault with intent to murder and stalking, evidentiary issues, arrest, and jury composition. It does not involve negligence, civil liability, supervision or custody of children, or any duty of reasonable care in a custodial/supervisory context. Accordingly, it provides no support for the stated Massachusetts tort-law proposition about negligent supervision of children.
Kennedy v. Town of Braintree, 60 Mass. A.relevant_excerpt: The convictions arise out of a turbulent and violent dating and, from time to time, cohabitation relationship that the defendant had with the victim. Most briefly summarized, the trial evidence was that, over the course of four years, the defendant engaged in a pattern of threats and acts of violence against the victim, was convicted of certain of these crimes, pleaded guilty to others, and then perpetrated anew further acts of violence against the victim. The level of violence escalated to a final attack, in which the defendant broke into the victim’s home and...

Powers v. Marine Midland Bank, 394 Mass..raw_text: Powers v. Marine Midland Bank, 394 Mass. 431 (1985) (general negligence principles)
Powers v. Marine Midland Bank, 394 Mass..proposition: The above statutes, Restatement sections, and cases are cited to reflect and support the well-established Massachusetts law principles that: a defendant who undertakes custodial or supervisory control over children owes a duty of reasonable care; that duty includes adequate staffing, active supervision, enforcement of safety rules, and reasonable measures to prevent foreseeable harm; and that a breach that is a proximate cause of harm gives rise to civil liability for resulting damages.
Powers v. Marine Midland Bank, 394 Mass..support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the reasonableness of a warrantless search of a vehicle’s locked trunk under the Fourth Amendment and Article 14 of the Massachusetts Constitution. It does not involve negligence, custodial or supervisory control over children, duties of reasonable care, staffing, supervision, or proximate cause in a tort context. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the Massachusetts negligence principles described in the proposition and is being cited for an unrelated legal issue.
Powers v. Marine Midland Bank, 394 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “We are thus holding that art. 14 of the Declaration of Rights requires the exclusion of evidence seized during a storage search not conducted pursuant to standard police procedures.… A warrantless search conducted without consent, without probable cause, and without exigent circumstances justifying the intrusion (such as protection against potential danger), but conducted pursuant to standard procedures, will have a greater chance of meeting constitutional requirements than an ad hoc practice such as is involved in this case.”

Fanning v. Levin, 360 Mass. 734 (1971) (.raw_text: Fanning v. Levin, 360 Mass. 734 (1971) (causation and foreseeability)
Fanning v. Levin, 360 Mass. 734 (1971) (.proposition: The above statutes, Restatement sections, and cases are cited to reflect and support the well-established Massachusetts law principles that: a defendant who undertakes custodial or supervisory control over children owes a duty of reasonable care; that duty includes adequate staffing, active supervision, enforcement of safety rules, and reasonable measures to prevent foreseeable harm; and that a breach that is a proximate cause of harm gives rise to civil liability for resulting damages.
Fanning v. Levin, 360 Mass. 734 (1971) (.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns probate, testamentary capacity, and testamentary intent in the context of a will contest. It does not involve custodial or supervisory control over children, duties of supervision, staffing, safety rules, foreseeability, or proximate cause of physical harm. Therefore it provides no authority for the negligence and custodial duty principles described in the proposition and is being cited out of context for that purpose.
Fanning v. Levin, 360 Mass. 734 (1971) (.relevant_excerpt: "The petitioner appeals from a decree entered in the Probate Court dismissing her petition to revoke the allowance of a will. The sole ground upon which she bases her petition was the existence of a subsequently discovered will. The issues raised by this appeal concern the testamentary intent of the testator, his testamentary capacity to execute the subsequent instrument, and the judge’s rulings as to the admission of certain evidence."

Santiago v. Fenton, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 67.raw_text: Santiago v. Fenton, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 674 (2005) (duty to protect from third-party acts)
Santiago v. Fenton, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 67.proposition: The above statutes, Restatement sections, and cases are cited to reflect and support the well-established Massachusetts law principles that: a defendant who undertakes custodial or supervisory control over children owes a duty of reasonable care; that duty includes adequate staffing, active supervision, enforcement of safety rules, and reasonable measures to prevent foreseeable harm; and that a breach that is a proximate cause of harm gives rise to civil liability for resulting damages.
Santiago v. Fenton, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 67.support_reasoning: This opinion is about contract and quantum meruit recovery for services rendered to an adult relative and about harmonizing special jury verdicts; it does not involve custodial or supervisory control over children, duties to protect from third-party acts, or standards of staffing, supervision, and safety rules. The case turns on whether quantum meruit recovery is consistent with the existence of an unbreached contract, not on tort duties owed to children. It therefore does not support the stated Massachusetts law proposition regarding custodial duties toward children and prevention of foreseeable harm.
Santiago v. Fenton, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 67.relevant_excerpt: "The defendant correctly notes that, where a valid contract covers the subject matter of dispute, 'the law need not create a quantum meruit right to receive compensation for services rendered,' Boswell v. Zephyr Lines, Inc., 414 Mass. 241, 250 (1993), but his claim that the special verdicts are inconsistent assumes that the contract and the quantum meruit based damages covered the same services provided by Satya and Sushila."

Mattson v. Department of Mental Health,.raw_text: Mattson v. Department of Mental Health, 397 Mass. 580 (1986) (standard of care for custodial supervision)
Mattson v. Department of Mental Health,.proposition: The above statutes, Restatement sections, and cases are cited to reflect and support the well-established Massachusetts law principles that: a defendant who undertakes custodial or supervisory control over children owes a duty of reasonable care; that duty includes adequate staffing, active supervision, enforcement of safety rules, and reasonable measures to prevent foreseeable harm; and that a breach that is a proximate cause of harm gives rise to civil liability for resulting damages.
Mattson v. Department of Mental Health,.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about admissibility of bite-mark identification evidence, joint venture, felony-murder based on rape, prosecutorial argument, and plenary review under G.L. c. 278, § 33E. It does not involve custodial or supervisory control over children, standards of care, staffing, active supervision, safety rules, or civil negligence liability. Thus it does not address, much less establish, the tort duty principles described in the proposition and is mis-cited for that purpose.
Mattson v. Department of Mental Health,.relevant_excerpt: There can be no doubt that this evidence was damaging to the defendant as it identified him as the one who bit the victim and also placed him at the scene of the murder. The defendant contends that the admission of the experts’ opinions created reversible error, and that they should not have been allowed to render their opinions because no foundation was laid to demonstrate that bite mark identification techniques have gained acceptance in the scientific community. We reject this contention because the admissibility of bite mark evidence does not depend on such a general acceptance.

Gicca v. City of Springfield, 407 Mass..raw_text: Gicca v. City of Springfield, 407 Mass. 380 (1990) (standard of care and municipal liability for recreation programs)
Gicca v. City of Springfield, 407 Mass..proposition: The above statutes, Restatement sections, and cases are cited to reflect and support the well-established Massachusetts law principles that: a defendant who undertakes custodial or supervisory control over children owes a duty of reasonable care; that duty includes adequate staffing, active supervision, enforcement of safety rules, and reasonable measures to prevent foreseeable harm; and that a breach that is a proximate cause of harm gives rise to civil liability for resulting damages.
Gicca v. City of Springfield, 407 Mass..support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the Governor’s statutory authority to withhold or limit state aid to municipalities and the validity of certain budgetary provisions. It does not address tort law, standards of care, supervision of children, municipal liability for recreational programs, or any duty of reasonable care. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the custodial/supervisory duty proposition described.
Gicca v. City of Springfield, 407 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the Governor had no authority under G.L. c. 29, §§ 9B and 9C (1988 ed.), to withhold $210,000,000 in local school aid funds, commonly called Chapter 70 aid, appropriated in the fiscal year 1990 budget.... We further hold, on an entirely separate issue, that § 6 of St. 1989, c. 240, lawfully limits distributions of certain State lottery proceeds to cities and towns during the 1989 and 1990 fiscal years.
